book_title: Names of the Horses of the Arabs and Their Knights
text:
In the name of Allah, the Most Gracious, the Most Merciful.
Abu al-Bakhtari reported, raising it [to the Prophet], that he said: The Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, said: "Keep these horses, for they are the legacy of your father Ishmael. They were wild animals, so he prayed to his Lord and He subjected them to him."
It is said: The origin of the Arab horses is from a horse that Solomon, peace be upon him, gave to people from the Amalekites called: Zad al-Rakib.
Ibn Habib said: Zad al-Rakib sired Al-Hajisi, which was better than it, and Al-Hajisi sired Al-Dinari, which was better than it.
Anas bin Mudrik said:
'Our father was the one before whom horses were not ridden... Nor did any tribe before him know how to ride.'

book_title: Names of the Horses of the Arabs and Their Knights
text:
Yaqub bin Muhammad al-Zuhri said: Abdul Aziz bin Imran told me from Ibrahim bin Ismail bin Abi Habiba al-Ashhali from Dawud bin al-Husayn from Ikrimah from Ibn Abbas who said: Horses were wild animals not ridden, and the first to ride them was Ishmael, so that is why they were called 'Arab' [horses].

**Naming of the Horses of Banu Hashim**
The Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, had five horses: Al-Zarib, Lizaz, Al-Sakb, and Al-Murtajiz. Al-Murtajiz was named so because of the beauty of its neighing.
Ibn Habib said: And he, peace be upon him, had: Al-Lahif.
He said: Al-Sakb was a kumayt (reddish-brown with black mane/tail) with a blaze (white mark on forehead) and white on three legs, except the right foreleg.
Yaqub bin Muhammad al-Zuhri said: Ibrahim bin Ja'far al-Ansari told me from...

book_title: Names of the Horses of the Arabs and Their Knights
text:
...his father who said: The Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, had a horse called: Dhu al-Limmah.
Ja'far bin Abi Talib had a female sorrel horse called: Sabhah. He was martyred on it, may Allah have mercy on him, on the Day of Mu'tah. He hamstrung it, so it was the first horse hamstrung in Islam. It is said: The Kharijites hamstring [horses] because of that.
Muhammad said: Al-Mawtah: A stupor that takes a person when it overwhelms his mind. Al-Mawtah: That a person dies a single death.
It is said: Hamza bin Abd al-Muttalib had a horse called: Al-Ward. He said about it:
'I have nothing but a weapon and Al-Ward... A full-grown horse from the daughters of Dhu al-Uqal.
I protect it from wars with myself... And it faces the chests of spears before me.
A large-bodied horse; what war strikes of it... when its heroes heat up, I do not care.
And a sharp one as if it were a bull's horn... That, not other than that, is most of my wealth.
And if I perish, it will be my legacy... and buckets praised among my buckets (deeds).'

**Horses of Quraysh**
He said: Ibrahim bin Ja'far al-Ansari informed me from Sa'd bin Sa'id bin Qays...

book_title: Names of the Horses of the Arabs and Their Knights
text:
...al-Ansari who said: The first to keep a horse for the sake of Allah was Sa'd bin Abi Waqqas.
Sufyan bin Uyayna from Al-Mas'udi from Al-Qasim bin Abd al-Rahman who said: The first whose horse ran with him in the sake of Allah was Al-Miqdad bin al-Aswad.
Al-Zubayr bin al-Awwam had a horse called: Al-Ya'sub, and a horse he witnessed Khaybar on called: Ma'ruf. He also had a horse called: Dhu al-Khimar which he witnessed the Day of the Camel on.
Ibn Habib said: He had a mare called: Dhat al-Ni'al upon which he was killed on the day of Wadi al-Siba'.
Al-Miqdad bin Amr, and Al-Aswad bin Abd Yaghuth al-Zuhri his step-son and ally—who is one of the mockers mentioned by Allah Almighty in His Book—had a horse...

book_title: Names of the Horses of the Arabs and Their Knights
text:
...which he witnessed Badr on called: Dhu al-Unuq. And he had a horse he witnessed the Day of Al-Sarh on called: Ba'zajah.
Ukasha bin Mihsan al-Asadi, ally of Banu Umayya, had a horse called: Dhu al-Limmah. He also had a horse he witnessed the Day of Al-Sarh on called: Janah.
Abu Dharr al-Ghifari had a horse called: Al-Ajdhal.
Bakir, one of Banu al-Shaddakh, had a horse called: Atlal. People say that on the day of Al-Mada'in he said to it: 'Jump, Atlal!' She turned to him and said: 'Yes, by the Surah of Al-Baqarah.' Then he witnessed Azerbaijan with Al-Shammakh and was martyred on it. Al-Shammakh said mourning him:
'And Bakir of Banu al-Shaddakh, the knight of Atlal... was absent from horses in Muqan that were safe.'
The horse of Suraqa bin Malik bin Ju'shum al-Mudlaji, who followed the Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, was called: Al-Awd.
The horse of Abu Jahl bin Hisham was called: Majah.

book_title: Names of the Horses of the Arabs and Their Knights
text:
Ubayy bin Khalaf al-Jumahi's horse was called: Al-Awd.
Musafi' bin Abd al-Uzza, one of Banu Amir bin Lu'ayy, his horse was called: Al-Na'amah. He said about it:
'By Allah, I will not forget Al-Na'amah for a night... nor its day, until I rest my wrist [in death].'
The horse of Muhriz bin Nadlah, ally of Banu Abd Shams, was called: Al-Sarhan. He witnessed the Day of Al-Sarh on it.
The horse of Maslama bin Abd al-Malik was called: Al-Zill.
Muhammad said: The Day of Al-Sarh is the day Uyayna bin Hisn al-Fazari raided with his people and followers the pasture camels of Medina and went off with them. The Ansar followed them, defeated them, disgraced him, and recovered what was in his hand.

**Horses of the Ansar**
The horse of Sa'd bin Zayd al-Ashhali, its name was: Lahiq, and he witnessed the Day of Al-Sarh.
Abbad bin Bishr, one of Banu Haritha, his horse was called: Lamma', he witnessed the Day of Al-Sarh on it.

book_title: Names of the Horses of the Arabs and Their Knights
text:
Zuhayr bin Rafi' al-Harithi, his horse's name: Al-Masnun, he witnessed the Day of Al-Sarh on it.
Abu Qatada bin Rab'i, one of Banu Salama, his horse's name: Jarwah, and he witnessed the Day of Al-Sarh on it.
Mu'adh bin Ma'is al-Zuraqi witnessed the Day of Al-Sarh on the horse of Abu Ayyash Ubayd bin Muawiyah al-Zuraqi, called: Hilwah.
The horse of Abu Talha Zayd bin Sahl al-Najari was called: Mandub. The Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, rode it and said: 'We found it a sea [in speed].'

**Horses of Banu Asad**
Salama bin Hind al-Ghadiri, his horse was called: Ma'ruf. He said:
'I turn Ma'ruf against them as if he... when he swerves from the impact of spears, is enraged.'
Dithar bin Faq'as, his horse's name: Al-Manihah. He said:
'Bring the tether of Al-Manihah near me... War has kindled a blaze for roasting.'

book_title: Names of the Horses of the Arabs and Their Knights
text:
Fadalah bin Hind, his horse: Al-Zalim. He said about it:
'I set up for them the chest of Al-Zalim and a spear... sail-like in the head of a raging angry one.'
Jurayba bin al-Ashyam al-Faq'asi, his horse: Kharaj. He said about her:
'By Allah, they did not favor me, but... Kharaj favored me when she turned away.
She sweated and saved her throat as if she were... behind me and before me, a skin-bag of a water-carrier.'
Al-Ajalah: The water skin. Al-Mukhlif: The one who brings fresh water to the people from another place while they are at their spring camp.
Dirar bin al-Azwar al-Asadi, the killer of Malik bin Nuwayra al-Yarbu'i. Mutammim said about him:
'Excellent is the killed one, when the winds blow... under the shelter, your victim, O Ibn al-Azwar.
Did you invite him by Allah then betray him... If he had invited you with the like, he would not have betrayed.'
He said: And Umar bin al-Khattab was angry when he heard of Malik's killing. His [Dirar's] horse: Al-Muhabbar. He said about it:
'I made gambling arrows and the playing of singing girls... and wine, a prayer and supplication.'
"Sallaytu tasliyatan" (I prayed a prayer), and tasliya here means prayer.

book_title: Names of the Horses of the Arabs and Their Knights
text:
'And my charging on Al-Muhabbar in the thick of battle... and my striving in fighting the polytheists.
O Lord, let not my deal be cheated... for I have sold my family and wealth in exchange.'
He said: It reached us that he recited this poetry to the Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, and the Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, said: 'Your deal is not cheated.'
The horse of Tulayha bin Khuwaylid al-Faq'asi was called: Al-Hammalah. He said about her:
'I set up for them the chest of Al-Hammalah; indeed she is... accustomed to the saying of the armored heroes: Dismount.'
Janah: The horse of Hadhlam bin Khalid bin Amr al-Faq'asi.
Thadiq: The horse of Hajib bin Habib bin Khalid al-Mudallal. He said about it:
'She spent the night blaming me regarding Thadiq... to sell it, and her disobedience became serious.
Verily, your whispering about Thadiq... is the same to me as declaring it.
She said: Aid us with it, for I... see that the price of horses has increased.
I said: Did you not know that it is... beautiful of appearance, good?'

**Horses of Banu Dabbah**
The horse of Qaraba bin Uwayya al-Dabbi: Al-Faynan. He says to it:
'If Al-Faynan catches me up with a people... and I do not stab, then may my fingers be paralyzed.'
The horse of Al-Muthallam bin al-Mushakhkhar, one of Banu A'idha bin Taym Allah bin Bakr bin Sa'd bin...

book_title: Names of the Horses of the Arabs and Their Knights
text:
...Dabbah, was called: Suhaym. He said about it:
'She rose blaming me regarding Suhaym... to sell him, while the sleepers were asleep.
She says: I see your two sons have grown thin... they have disheveled heads, thirsty.
And there is nothing in it against me, so blame me... even if you prolonged the blame, [it is just] blame.'
And he says about it:
'Indeed the Merciful turned away from Suhaym... and its rider, the spears of Banu Tamim.
I made my horse and my throat a target... for the sharpness of their spears at Liwa al-Qasim.'
Zayd al-Fawaris, his horse: Shawlah. He said about her:
'I restricted for them from the chest of Shawlah; indeed... only the helpful hero saves from distress.'
He also had a horse called: Urqub. Abdullah bin Anamah al-Sayyidi said about it:
'You do not see the master Zayd in their souls... as Banu Kuz and Marhub see him.
So restrain your donkey, let it not graze in our meadow... when the shackled donkey comes to the water.
And let not Urqub be for you like the running of Dahis... in Ghatafan on the morning of the ravine.'
The horse of Al-Raqqad bin al-Mundhir bin Dirar al-Dabbi was called: Al-Kamil. He said about it:
'I continued driving Kamil and forcing him... against the people until they surrendered or scattered.'

book_title: Names of the Horses of the Arabs and Their Knights
text:
Abd al-Harith bin Dirar, his horse: Mabdu'. He said about it:
'Mabdu' complained of raiding and became... like the remains of the bridle, scarred.'
Al-Namir bin Tawlab al-Ukkli, his horse's name: Sahba. He said about her:
'Do the runs of Sahba go in vain... trembling against the enemies a trembling?
And my charging in the adversity every day... when voices mixed with dust?
A reddish-brown color, raising her tail... you think the whiteness of her blaze a lamp.'
Unayf bin Jabala al-Dabbi, ally of Banu Salit bin Yarbu', his horse: Al-Shit. He said about it:
'The stabbing harmed the throat of Al-Shit so he bent... So I forced him into the quivers until he advanced.'
Subay' bin al-Khatim al-Taymi, his horse: Nahla. He is called: Knight of Nahla. He proposed to his uncle's daughter, so he said to him: 'Yes, I will marry you my daughter on condition that you give me your mare Nahla.' He refused, and said about that:
'I saw Abu Shayma eager... when I speak to him at the head of a path.
He says: Nahla, or leave me. So I said to him... Rely on me for virgin large camels.
What would I say if I possessed [her] and they came early... with a long mare like a spear shaft, swift?
An oath persisted on me not to exchange her... for one with two earrings between the neck and the lava fields.'

book_title: Names of the Horses of the Arabs and Their Knights
text:
Al-Abkar: Those that have given birth once. And Al-Harajib: The tall fat ones. He said about her:
'I and Nahla, as long as I remain for her... the flank will not be at ease with selling her.
He who offers a high price for her knows... that what I have is the profit.'
Ajlan bin Nakrah al-Taymi, his horse: Hudhlul. He said about it when Al-Fazari raced him on it:
'I risked my colt in the bet for a need... and from stubbornness is what harms and benefits.
What did you want, O daughter of Malik... when my wealth was being torn apart at Al-Liwa?'
Qabisa bin Dirar al-Dabbi, his horse: Al-Ahwa. He said about it:
'Banu Sulaym say when they see me... on Al-Ahwa galloping with the rein:
On me is a coat of mail and with me is a spear... and its shaft, and it suffices you as a spearhead.'
And from Banu Dabbah, from Banu al-Sayyid, the Knight of Minhab, who is Uwayya bin Salma, who captured Rabi'a bin Khuwaylid, the uncle of Yazid bin Amr bin Khuwaylid, who is Al-Sa'iq. Uwayya said about him:
'My running and my exertion overtook Minhab... at Dhat al-Ghada, Rabi'a bin Khuwaylid.
A blazing one like the evening shower in his gathering... galloping like the wolf of the desert, ferocious.'

book_title: Names of the Horses of the Arabs and Their Knights
text:
And from Banu al-Sayyid, Al-Mu'ajjab bin Sufyan, his horse: Al-Kumayt, and that is its name. He said about it:
'As if I and Al-Kumayt drag my spear... at the dunes of Al-Sarif around a twisted path.
As if the splitting of skulls from us... and from them between us is the splitting of oyster shells.'
And from Banu Tha'labah bin Sa'd bin Dabbah, the Knight of Al-Shaqra', who is Rabi'a bin Ubayy. He fought bravely on the day of Naqa al-Hasan—it is said: Al-Husayn—the day they killed Bistam bin Qays; Asim bin Khalifa al-Sabahi killed him. It is also called: The Day of al-Dahna. Bistam had gone out to raid Banu Dabbah. Sham'ala bin al-Akhdar bin Hubayra bin al-Mundhir bin Dirar bin Amr said:
'And on the day of Shaqiqat al-Hasanayn, Banu Shayban... met short life spans.
We pierced with the spearhead while they were leaning... the ears of their ram until he spun around.
He remained on the oleander bush not cushioned... and blood was a veil for him.
You see Al-Shaqra' strutting in her afterbirth... and blood has become a wrap for her.
As the girl of the tribe struts in it amidst the virgins... in a borrowed cloak.
We give her the fresh milk when we winter... despite our needs, and we take the diluted milk.'
Al-Samar from milk is that which is two-thirds water or three-quarters water, and the rest milk.

book_title: Names of the Horses of the Arabs and Their Knights
text:
And the watered-down milk is less than it.
'Hoping that she will return it to us... from the enemies by force and compulsion.'
And from Banu Dabbah then from Banu Kuz, the Knight of Dhat al-Rimah. His mare, if frightened, Banu Dabbah would rejoice at booty. Regarding that, Al-Asamm, who is Qays bin As'as, one of Banu Abd Manat bin Bakr bin Sa'd bin Dabbah, says:
'If Dhat al-Rimah is frightened, she drags to us... lucky ones with birds whose spoils are many.'
And from Banu Abd Manat bin Bakr bin Sa'd bin Dabbah is Abu Sawaj, who is Abbad bin Khalaf, the Knight of Badhwah. He raced Surad bin Jamrah, the uncle of Malik bin Nuwayra, who was on his horse Al-Qatib, and Badhwah beat him. So Abu Sawaj said about that:
'Did you not see that Badhwah when we ran... and the running became serious, left Al-Qatib behind?
As if their Qatib when we ran... was a breaking eagle diving seeking prey.'

**Horses of Banu Sa'd bin Zayd Manat bin Tamim**
Al-Zibriqan bin Badr, his horse's name: Al-Raqib. He said about it:
'Indeed Al-Raqib, I treat him and tend to him... bare of cheek-straps, neither rude nor poor.'
Alqama bin Sibah, one of Banu Haddan bin Qari', his horse's name: Habud. The wailing woman of Amr bin al-Ja'id al-Muradi, who was killed on the Day of al-Kulab, said...

book_title: Names of the Horses of the Arabs and Their Knights
text:
...about it:
'The killing of a master turned the blackness of the head gray... and the Knight of Habud turned the forelocks gray.'
Al-Sulayk bin Sulaka al-Sa'di, his horse: Al-Nahham. He was called: The Knight of Al-Nahham. He said about it:
'Bring out Al-Nahham and hurry, O boy... and throw the saddle on him and the bridle.
And inform the youths that I am wading... the flood of death, so whoever wishes let him stay.'

**Horses of Amr bin Tamim**
And from Banu Amr bin Tamim: Ubayda bin Rabi'a bin Qahfan bin Nashira bin Sayyara bin Rizam bin Mazin. His horse is called: Sakab. He is the Knight of Sakab. He said about her:
'I refuse the curse, indeed Sakab is not... a precious thing to be borrowed or sold.
A descendant of two predecessors who produced her... a leg joins them when their lineage is traced.
Do not covet, I refuse the curse, in her... preventing you from her is in a way that is possible.'
Tarif bin Tamim bin Namiya, from Banu Adi bin Jundab bin al-Anbar, and he was called Mulqi al-Qina' (He who throws the veil), because he was the first to throw the veil at Ukaz and say: "Whoever wishes, let him seek me." The name of his horse was Al-Aghar. He said about it:

book_title: Names of the Horses of the Arabs and Their Knights
text:
'Beneath me is Al-Aghar and above my skin is a coat of mail... loose rings that repel the sword while it is notched.'

**Horses of Banu Hanzala**
Hawt bin Abi Jabir, from Banu Riyah bin Yarbu' bin Hanzala, his horse: Dhu al-Uqal. He is Abu Dahis. It was named Dhu al-Uqal because when ridden it would get tangled then extend. Jarir said:
'Indeed the steeds spend the night around our domes... from the family of A'waj and Dhu al-Uqal.'
Jalwa belonged to Qirwash bin Awf bin Asim bin Ubayd bin Tha'labah bin Yarbu', and she is the mother of Dahis.
Al-Kalhaba bin Hubayra al-Urayni, Urayn bin Tha'labah bin Yarbu', his horse's name: Al-Arada. He said about her:
'Banu Jusham bin Bakr ask me... Is Al-Arada blazing or dark?
She is the mare on which the Sheikh charged against you... like the noble lion.'
Wathil bin Awf al-Riyahi, Abu Suhaym bin Wathil, his horse: Lazim. Suhaym said about it:

book_title: Names of the Horses of the Arabs and Their Knights
text:
'And I said to the people of the ravine when they gambled with me... Did you not know that I am the son of the Knight of Lazim?'
Malik bin Nuwayra, his horses: Dhu al-Khimar, Nisab, Al-Wari'a, Al-Annab, and Al-Jawn. Malik said:
'My remedy and my art rewarded me with Dhu al-Khimar... when the folds of Banu al-Asaghir slept.'
He said: Banu Abs raided Banu Yarbu' and took the camels of Banu Hubba, so Malik bin Nuwayra rescued them. He said:
'The galloping and running of Al-Annab caught up with... the milk-camels of Ibn Hubba while he was sad and grieving.'
His mare Nisab broke, so Al-Farafisah bin al-Ahwas al-Kalbi mounted him on a horse called: Al-Wari'a. He says about her:
'I complained to them of my leg, so they said... to their master: We obey in the answer.
So he returned our friend with a gift of truth... and gave him Al-Wari'a after Nisab.'

book_title: Names of the Horses of the Arabs and Their Knights
text:
'So my friendship became stuffed in my saddle... with a long-bodied mare, wide-stepping in the sides.'
He said about Al-Jawn:
'Bring the tether of Al-Jawn near me for it... the time of dismounting has neared and the crowds have occupied the sides.'
Dawud bin Mutammim bin Nuwayra, his horse: Al-Dhabih. He said about it:
'I raised for them the chest of Al-Dhabih and missed me... litters from the belly of Iyad rising.'
Abu Milail Abdullah bin al-Harith bin Asim bin Ubayd bin Tha'labah bin Yarbu', his horse: Al-Alhan. Jarir said about it:
'Shabath I boasted of against you and Ma'qal... and Abu Milail the Knight of Al-Alhan.'
Jarir said:
'Bring the like of Qa'nab and Al-Alhan... or like Abu Hazra, the poison of knights.'
Abu Hazra is Utaybah bin al-Harith bin Shihab.
'And Ibn Hana'ah is not slow or weak... nor weak in meeting peers.'
Al-Bara' bin Qays bin Attab bin Harami bin Riyah bin Yarbu', his horse's name: Al-Gharraf. He said about it:

book_title: Names of the Horses of the Arabs and Their Knights
text:
'If Al-Gharraf were to exchange a rider... other than me, I would have exchanged Al-Samayda' for him.'
Al-Samayda': Name of a man he had captured.
Utaybah bin al-Harith bin Shihab, his horse: Al-Mukassar. Malik bin Nuwayra said about him:
'If the loins of it (camels) were fat, they would have crowded... Utaybah when the forehead of Al-Mukassar bled.'
Usayd bin Hana'ah al-Saliti, the Knight of Al-Shaqra'.
Tariq bin Hasbah bin Aznam bin Ubayd bin Tha'labah bin Yarbu', the Knight of Hayfa'. It is said: Hayfa' is the full sister of Dahis.
The horse of Laqit bin Zurara, Al-Ashqar, and its name was Saddam. Jabalah said about it:
'Advance, Saddam, they are Banu Abs... the majestic tribe among the strict people.'
Damrah bin Jabir bin Qatan bin Nahshal, his horse: Wabal.

book_title: Names of the Horses of the Arabs and Their Knights
text:
'Lo, who will convey from me to Dhubab... the fly of arms, what a youth sees her!
If you met me with Wabal among them... I would help the slave stabbing in her peaks.'
Ubayd bin Malik al-Nahshali, his horse: Al-Fahdah. He is called: The Knight of Al-Fahdah.

**Horses of Bahilah**
Rabi'a bin Mudlij, one of Banu Sahb, the Knight of Haddaj. The poet said about him:
'Shaqiq and Hurayy shed our blood... and the Knight of Haddaj turned the forelocks gray.'
Shaqiq bin Hurayy, the Knight of Mayyas. The poet said about him:
'Noses from Abd bin Ghanm, their father... was noble, so he vied in nobility and produced noble offspring.
The knights of Sala on the day of Sala and Sajir... and the Knight of Mayyas when he prepared for battle.'
Sumayr bin Rabi'a bin Khalaf bin Murra bin Sahb, the Knight of Khasaf, which is the name of his horse. The poet said about him:
'Or like the Lord of Khasaf when he charges him... against the armed heroes, he splits skulls and necks.'
Amir bin Ma'bad, the Knight of Al-Raq'a, sister of Khasaf.

book_title: Names of the Horses of the Arabs and Their Knights
text:
Uqba bin Mudlij al-Alimi, he had Al-Harun and Al-Mu'alla.
Salim bin Arta'ah al-Alimi, he had Al-Sarhan.
A'waj, belonging to Adi bin Ayyub bin Shabib al-Alimi.
Abu Qurba, the horse of Ubayd bin Azhar, client of Amr bin Jabir al-Bahili.
Daysam bin Rumi al-Bahili, his horse: Al-Kumayt. Daysam says about it to Umayr bin al-Hubab:
'So Al-Kumayt overtook him with a brisk one... of the heroes, a noble raider.'
Al-Shammari: Brisk. Al-Mighwar: From raiding. Al-Najib: Noble and strong.
The horse of Shabib bin Daysam is called: Al-Wazn.
The horse of Hatim bin al-Nu'man al-Bahili, its name: Al-Ward.

**Horses of Ghani bin A'sur**
Shaytan bin al-Hakam bin Jahima bin Harraq, his horse: Al-Khadhwa'. He said about her...

book_title: Names of the Horses of the Arabs and Their Knights
text:
...on the Day of Mahjar: 'Whoever takes a hair from the tail of Al-Khadhwa' is safe.'
Tufayl said:
'Al-Khadhwa' bestowed a favor upon them... and Shaytan when he calls them and returns.'
The Knight of Al-Hammham from Banu Zabban bin Ka'b bin Jalan bin Ghanm bin Ghani.
Al-Mushamma'l bin Hazlah, his horse: Kharqah.
And belonging to Ghani: Al-Ghurab, Al-Wajih, Lahiq, and Al-Mudhhib.

**Horses of Ghatafan bin Sa'd**
Amir bin Qays bin Jundab al-Ashja'i, the Knight of Al-Farafar.
Amir bin al-Harith bin Subay', the Knight of Al-Adud.
Jabir bin Abdullah said:
'They shake linear spears, and their horses... are extending like the eagles of Talal, the breakers.
On every high-looking horse with abundant hair... and every lean mare like a stick, slim.
Smooth of running, shook in its mothers... daughters of Al-Adud or daughters of Al-Farafar.'

book_title: Names of the Horses of the Arabs and Their Knights
text:
Qays bin Zuhayr bin Jadhimah, his two horses: Dahis and Al-Ghabra'.
Muzarrad said to Banu Anmar and their ally:
'With my hand I threw the stick and bought them... with a settled tribe who confine the prisoners.
With the tribe of Banu Sa'd bin Dhubyan when he saw... with me at Anmar Sarab and Dahis.'
Sarab: Is Al-Ghabra'. Abu Ja'far said: Sarab is the she-camel of Al-Basus over which the war between Bakr and Taghlib occurred.
'I was like one who gave noble healthy camels... for a scabby one that infects whoever comes to it touching.'
Antara bin Abd bin Muawiyah, his horses: Al-Aghar, Al-Adham, and Ibn al-Na'amah. He said about Al-Adham:
'They call Antar while the spears are like... ropes of a well in the breast of Al-Adham.'
He said about Al-Aghar:

book_title: Names of the Horses of the Arabs and Their Knights
text:
'May Allah reward Al-Aghar a truthful reward... when the fire of wars is kindled.
He protects me with his forehead and shoulders... and I help him with moderate heels.'
It is said: He had a horse called: Al-Abjar, or it belonged to someone else among them. He said:
'Do not hurry, I tighten the belt of Al-Abjar... I, when death approaches, do not panic.
And I did not promise the soul delay.'
Shaddad bin Muawiyah, Antara's uncle, the Knight of Jarwah. He said about her:
'Whoever asks about me, then I... and Jarwah do not seek forage nor are we lent.'
Hudhayfah bin Badr, his two horses: Al-Khattar and Al-Hanfa'.
Hujr bin Muawiyah bin Hudhayfah, his horse: Al-Hanfa'.
Shabib bin Muawiyah bin Hudhayfah, the Knight of Al-Sakb. That is the name of his horse.
Yazid bin Sinan al-Murri, his horse: Wajzah. He said about her:

book_title: Names of the Horses of the Arabs and Their Knights
text:
'I shot them with Wajzah when they advised each other... to shoot her throat from near and my throat.
When she penetrated them, she returned against them... as if her foal was among them and my young camel.'
Sinan bin Abi Haritha, his horse: Barjah.
Muzahim: The horse of Talha bin Abi Mihjan al-Adawi.
And belonging to Ghatafan: Al-Asjadi, and Lahiq. Al-Nabigha said:
'Among them are daughters of Al-Asjadi and Lahiq... ash-colored, their spur-places from the training ground.'
Hizam bin Wabisa, his horse: Al-Raqim. He said:
'And horses like sandgrouse, the grazing livestock of the tribe pastured among them... Al-Raqim leads me.'
Dabi'a bin al-Harith al-Absi, his horse: Al-Aghar.
Zabban bin Sayyar al-Fazari, his horse: Silm. Zayd al-Khayl gave it to him, and he escaped on it while he was a captive among Banu Badr. Zabban said:
'You bestowed favor, so do not deny my trial and favor... and let Silm pay you as he paid you.'
Al-Rabi' bin Ziyad, his horse: Al-Ya'bub. He was called: The Knight of Ya'bub.

book_title: Names of the Horses of the Arabs and Their Knights
text:
Marwan al-Qaraz said:
'I returned Khuma'ah to Awf after... Dhu'ab unveiled her, not the unveiling of a suitor.
If she had been the spoil of anyone else's spear... he would have brought her tied by the forelocks.
But he cast his protection over her... hoping for reward or fearing consequences.
So I defended her with Nashib and his tribe... and the Knight of Ya'bub and Zayd bin Qarib.
I struck Banu Shayban regarding her with a favor... spoken of by the people of Sala and Marib.'
Sala and Marib: Two lands.
Al-Ghurab bin Salim al-Absi, his horse: Al-Mukh.
And belonging to Abs also: Al-Bashir.

**Horses of Banu Sulaym**
The horse of Umayr bin al-Hubab: Al-Za'faran. He said about it:
'I have overlooked a land I love... If I wish, Al-Za'faran trots and gallops.'
Al-Abbas bin Mirdas al-Sulami, his horse: Al-Ubayd. He said about it:
'Do you make the spoil of Al-Ubayd... between Uyayna and Al-Aqra'?

book_title: Names of the Horses of the Arabs and Their Knights
text:
'Neither Hisn nor Habis was... superior to Mirdas in a gathering.
Nor was I below either of them... and whomever war lowers is not raised.'
He also had: Zirrah, which Sufyan bin Awf al-Nasri took, then it was rescued from him.
He also had: Sawbah. He said about her:
'I prepared Sawbah and Al-Samut and my spear... and the extra armor gleams like white cloth.
Outstripping the rein as if her bridle is... in the head of a tall palm tree.
Between Al-Hammalah and Al-Qurayt she has... produced noble offspring from a mother and a stallion.'
Al-Qurayt and Al-Hammalah: Two horses.
The horse of Muawiyah bin Mirdas was called: Zamil. He said about it:
'By my life, I have increased exposing Zamil... to a wound or to curb a wild ass.
There is no likeness in his days and trial... like a day he had at Al-Jarr, if you knew.
The upper parts of Samhari spears pierce his chest... and they shoot arrows at his vertebrae.'
Meaning the vertebrae of his neck.
'So will Abu Salama thank my favor?... My thought of him is that he will be found thankful.'
Abu Salama: A man from Banu Sulaym.

book_title: Names of the Horses of the Arabs and Their Knights
text:
And Muawiyah bin Mirdas also had a horse called: Al-Adham. He said about it:
'If you take Al-Adham, you will not surpass me.
Stretching when urged after fatigue.'
Al-Sati: Wide-stepping. Tutia bi-inanihi: Urged by hand after tiring, he springs.
'Filling his two girths and filling the eye.
Puffing two nostrils after panting.
Like the puffing of two bellows in the hands of a blacksmith.'
The horse of Hazn bin Mirdas: Al-Has'sa'. He was called: The Knight of Al-Has'sa'. He said:
'Were it not for Allah and Al-Has'sa', my family would have perished... while she shows her veins.
I have not seen the like of a run I made her catch up... at Awtas to a rebellious caravan.
When the spears fell towards her, she dangled... the dangling of an eagle from the top of a mountain peak.'
Qays bin Nashba al-Sulami, his horse: Saddam. He said about it:
'O family of Bakr, be patient for it, for I... am Qays and Saddam is the Lion.'
Al-Asad: The name of his armor.
Ibn Adiya al-Aslami, was an ally to Banu Usayyah, his horse's name: Al-Ward.

book_title: Names of the Horses of the Arabs and Their Knights
text:
He said about it:
'Al-Ward rewarded me with my limbs and my protection... and his praise was great to me and good.'
Kazaz, the horse of Husayn bin Alqama al-Dhakwani, who is Husayn al-Fawaris. He said about her:
'I turned Kazaz towards the chest of Al-Latim... until they were like in a rope.
And I was certain that I was a perishing man... so I risked myself for good praise.
I left Fadalah in a battlefield... grappling with a red one like a rope.
And they, with us drinking in the dust... run the running of energetic young camels.'
Al-Ifal: Young camels. Al-Sanan: Activity/Energy.
The horse of Khufaf bin Umayr, who is Ibn Nudba: Alwa. He said about her on the day he killed Malik bin Himar al-Fazari:
'If my horses have been hit in their core... then putting the sword back in the sheath, upon my eye, I aimed at Malik.
I set up Alwa for him when my companionship recoiled... to prefer glory or avenge a dead one.
I said to him while the spear bent his back... Look slowly, indeed I am that one.'

**Horses of Hawazin**
Banu Hilal have: A'waj. Then to Banu al-Muharibiyah from Banu Manaf bin Hilal,

book_title: Names of the Horses of the Arabs and Their Knights
text:
The poet said about them:
'The daughters of A'waj came to you bridled... by the sons of the chaste women of Nizar.'
Al-Hawasin, Abu Abdullah said: Those who have husbands, and similar to them are Al-Ghawani.
Abdullah bin Shurahbil al-Hilali, the Knight of Al-Jaradah.
Amr bin Amir bin Rabi'a bin Amir bin Sa'sa'ah, the Knight of Al-Dahya'. Khidash bin Zuhayr said:
'My father is the Knight of Al-Dahya', Amr bin Amir... He refused blame and chose loyalty over treachery.'
Khalid bin Ja'far bin Kilab, his horse: Hadhfah. He said about it:
'Whoever asks about me, then I... and Hadhfah are like the obstruction under the jugular vein.
A honored mare, I feed her a portion... and cover her with my cloak in the frost.
And I instruct the two shepherds to give her the evening drink... the milk of the milk-camel and the premature mother.'
Al-Khaliyah: The one who nurses another's young to produce milk, and her milk is for her family. Al-Sa'ud: The one who casts her young prematurely and nurses another's young.

book_title: Names of the Horses of the Arabs and Their Knights
text:
Al-Ghabuq: The evening drink.
'Perhaps Allah will enable me openly... against her from Zuhayr or Usayd.'
Zuhayr and Usayd: The two sons of Jadhimah.
Tufayl bin Malik bin Ja'far bin Kilab bin Rabi'a bin Amir bin Sa'sa'ah, the Knight of Qurzul. Salama bin al-Khurshub said about him:
'Indeed you, O uncle of the Knight of Qurzul... are a repeater of foul speech and obscenities.'
He says: You repeat foul speech time after time.
Dabi'a bin al-Harith al-Absi said about him:
'And you did the deed of your father, the Knight of Qurzul... Indeed the fleeing one is the son of every fleeing one.'
Al-Nadud: The defeated one who flees when meeting war.
Amir bin al-Tufayl bin Malik had: Hanwah, Al-Hammalah, Al-Maznuq, and Al-Kalb. He is called: The Knight of Al-Kalb. He said about Al-Maznuq:
'Al-Maznuq knew that I attack... on the evening of Fayf al-Rih, the attack of the circumambulator.'

book_title: Names of the Horses of the Arabs and Their Knights
text:
He said: Al-Mudawwir: The one who circumambulates the idol worshipping it.
Salama bin al-Khurshub said to Amir:
'You escaped with the blade of a sword with no sheath over it... and a saddle on the back of Al-Hammalah, fitting.'
Al-Qatir: That which fits the rider with no tightness or looseness.
'If she were running then, we would have caught her... but they follow the image of a bird.'
Amir also had: Al-Ward. Mayya bint Ahban al-Absiyya said mentioning Amir's horse:
'Were it not for the speed of Al-Ward, its wing fluttering... and the command of God—there is no defeater of God—
You would have inhabited this year Nafa' and Man'ij... the lands of enemies, or loved ones would have wept for you.'
Man'ij: A village on the road from Basra to Mecca. Nafa': A place near it.
Abd Amr bin Shurayh bin al-Ahwas, the Knight of Da'laj. He said about it:
'You are divorced if you do not ask which knight... your husband was when he met Sada' and Khath'am.
And the day we met the gathering of Dhubyan and the spears... were thirsty, so we quenched their points with blood.'

book_title: Names of the Horses of the Arabs and Their Knights
text:
'I advance Da'laj among them and force him... If spears are forced into him, he neighs.
Meeting the tips of spears that pierced him... like the piercing of a cracked vessel by a repairer.'
Durayd bin al-Simma, his horse: Ajla. He said about her:
'I say to Ajla: It is but an hour... May my soul be your ransom, catch me up with my pursuers.'
Tawba bin al-Humayyir, his horse: Al-Khawsa'. He said about her:
'Tawba called Al-Khawsa' when deaths... assaulted him, and escape was barred.'
He gave Qabisa, his cousin, A'waj, his horse on which he escaped, and it was a bay (Ward).
Jaz' bin Shurayh bin al-Ahwas, his horse: Al-Harun. He said about it:
'I set up for them the chest of Al-Harun as if they were... at his manure pile, until a promised time comes.
If they chase him, the spear is possible in them... and if they chase him, he intends the enemy.'
Abu Abdullah Muhammad said: Rabi'a bin Amir bin Malik asked his brother Abu Hurayra bin Amir bin Malik to carry him, but he did not carry him. He obtained a horse called: Nathil, and said:

book_title: Names of the Horses of the Arabs and Their Knights
text:
'If you were the owner of wealth, you would not be found on foot... and isolate the surplus of horses from you an isolation.
I permitted you to buy with their surplus... and I prepared Nathil for enemies and war.
I favored him over my family and softened his saddle cloth... and my weaning camels until they wintered as runts.'
Hasakil: Emaciated ones, which are young camels that did not drink enough milk.
The Knight of Khizam is a man from Banu Qushayr called: Hatim bin Hiyyash, one of Banu al-A'war bin Qushayr. His leg was cut off at Tustar, so he charged the polytheists saying:
'Advance Khudham, they are the Chosroes.
Advance and do not let a flying leg deceive you.
I am the Qushayri, brother of the emigrants.
I strike with the sword the heads of the disbelievers.'
Shabib bin Jarad, one of Banu al-Wahid, his horse: Al-Shamus. He said:
'I set up for them the chest of Al-Shamus, and I see... the place of flight if I wanted flight.
If they turn away, I shoot them from a Persian bow... I showed Haram a dirham and Suhar.'
He said: Banu Nufatha bin Abdullah bin Kilab bet Banu al-Ahwas bin Ja'far bin Kilab on a slave girl and thirty camels. Banu Nufatha won on a horse belonging to Rabi'a bin Amr bin Nufatha called: Ahlub. Rabi'a bin Amr is called: The Knight of Ahlub. They took the slave girl of Banu Ja'far, who was called: Jahira. She gave birth among Banu al-Samut. Among those she bore was Salam bin Hubaysh. When Salam and Al-A'war exchanged satire, Al-A'war said...

book_title: Names of the Horses of the Arabs and Their Knights
text:
...Al-A'war taunting Salam about Jahira:
'What is our fault if Ahlub ran... between Watir or Hazim al-Muntasa?
While your mother was sitting at the goal.'
Yazid bin al-Tathriya, his horse: Al-Kumayt. He said:
'By your lives, Al-Kumayt is entrusted... despite pain, to complete five [days] after five.'
Ja'da bin Mirdas al-Numayri, his horse: Junbar. Ma'qil bin Himar al-Bariqi said about it:
'He presents Junbar with a notched sword... having an edge that whenever it attained, it cut.'
And from Banu Nasr bin Muawiyah, the Knight of Mahaj, who is Malik bin Awf. He says to it on the Day of Hunayn:
'Advance Mahaj, it is a day of denial.
One like me protects and attacks against one like you.'
Abs bin Haddar, from Banu Wa'il bin Sa'sa'ah bin Muawiyah, the Knight of...

book_title: Names of the Horses of the Arabs and Their Knights
text:
...Qadid. He said to his horse on the Day of al-Raqam:
'Advance Qadid, do not be a shrinking one.
I will surely stab a gushing stab.
Having a spray that scatters the army.
He who does not duel will not be a chief.'
Qalus: Gushing with blood. It is said: A gushing stab.
Amir bin al-Tufayl says about him:
'And Abu Ubayy, I have not heard of his like... Oh how excellent he is, evening and day.'
And from Banu Nufayl bin Amr bin Kilab, the Knight of Saddam, who is Zufar bin al-Harith. He said to his horse:
'Advance Saddam, he is the son of Bahdal.
The horses will not overtake while you walk wearily.
Except with a passing like the passing of the hawk.'
Awf bin al-Ahwas, the Knight of Mijlaz. He also had Al-Asa.
Muawiyah bin Julaymid bin Ubada bin al-Baka' bin Amir bin Rabi'a bin Amir bin...

book_title: Names of the Horses of the Arabs and Their Knights
text:
...Sa'sa'ah, the Knight of Hajna'.

**Horses of Rabi'a bin Nizar**
Al-Lajjaj bin Abdullah said:
'Mudar and Anmar gifted their brother... Abu Asad Rabi'a with the steeds.'
Yahya bin Mansur said:
'Nizar was more knowing when he bequeathed... to which of his sons he bequeathed the donkey.
And which of them is more deserving of every noble horse... twisting in the soft ground and the soft earth.'
Al-Riqaq: The wide place.

**Horses of Banu Dabi'a bin Nizar**
He said: Al-Safra' belonged to Al-Harith al-Adjam.
Al-Ray' was the horse of Amr bin Asm, and he is the Knight of Al-Ray', and by it he is known.
Yazid al-Ghawani said, boasting and counting their men:
'And the lord of Al-Ray' Al-Safra' is of us... and the rulers of the tribe all of them.'
Mukhayyil bin Shijna, the Knight of (Al-Matar). He said:
'I wore Al-Sirat and Dhat Shakk... and I preferred Al-Matar over the family.'

book_title: Names of the Horses of the Arabs and Their Knights
text:
Al-Sirat: The cutting sword. Al-Shakk: The nails, and the nails are the armors (ghala'il), singular ghalalah. Heads of nails: Al-Harabi, singular hirba'. Also, the elevations of the ground and the chameleons of the ground, nothing else.
Abu Abdullah said: Sa'd bin Mushammit swore not to see a prisoner but release him. His brother Al-Jalis bin al-Mushammit was captured by Jayfar bin al-Julanda. He said: 'I will not release you until you bring me such and such.' He began making conditions on him. Among what he stipulated was that he bring him the two horses of his brother Sa'd bin Mushammit: Al-Khayfaq and Al-Asa. Sa'd delayed him, so he recited poems about him. Among what he said was:
'How many a Khayfaq and Asa I was reclaiming... and one like me throughout time is reclaimed.'
He did not release him until Al-Musayyab bin Alas said about him:
'I am a man sending a greeting in absence... to Ibn Julanda, the Knight of horses, Jayfar.'
Al-Akhnas bin Ghiyath al-Dabu'i said:
'You continued calling Al-Ra'i'at, so your caller did not flag... until the calamities descended upon you.
Tawalah, Al-Shaqa', Al-Fayd, and Al-Shaqa... varied at times and at a time followed in succession.'

book_title: Names of the Horses of the Arabs and Their Knights
text:
**Horses of Anazah bin Asad**
Uqba bin Salim al-Hazzani, the Knight of Mayyah. He said about it:
'I treated Mayyah for her and trained him... So I treated a filler of the eye in which there is no claim.'
And it is narrated: 'So I emerged a filler of the eye in which there are claims.'
He says: No horse of the Arabs hopes to outstrip him.
'As for when you are behind him, he is wide-bellied... As for when you face him, he is long-jawed.'
Al-Hashur: Wide-bellied. Al-Saljam: Long-cheeked, long-necked.
'And as for when you view him from the side, he is large-bodied... And he has a high back with long ribs and girth.'
Habi: Full, long ribs.
'He has the neck of a gazelle and the legs of an ostrich... and the sciatic nerves of a wolf whose flesh is chopped.'
Abaya bin Shaks al-Hazzani, his horse: Al-Hammalah. He said about her:
'I set up for them the chest of Al-Hammalah; indeed she... when the heroes recoil, I say to her: Advance.
As if the sail-like [ears] around her cheek-straps are... the secondary feathers of a black raven.'

**Horses of Abd al-Qays bin Afsa**
Suwayd bin Khadhaq al-Shanni, his horse: Al-Shamus. He said about it:

book_title: Names of the Horses of the Arabs and Their Knights
text:
'Does she know that Hazim complained... to me and that I rode Al-Shamus?
I treated her until she wintered Abyssinian (black)... as if upon her was sundus and sadus.'
Habashiyyah: Black, meaning dark bay. Sundus: The yalanjaq. Sadus: A black thing.
Yazid bin Khadhaq, his horse: Sam'ar. He said about her:
'I prepared Sam'ar after she shed her milk teeth... and wore the armor of a skin belt.
You will not combine my affection and my blame... until two swords are combined in one sheath.'
Al-Rayyan bin Huways, from Banu Amir bin al-Harith, his horse: Al-Hirawah. He used to give it to the bachelors of his people; when a man became self-sufficient, he gave it to another.
And belonging to Banu Amir bin al-Harith: Jalwa, mentioned by some of their poets.
Mazyada al-Muharibi, from Abd Qays, his horse Al-Mutatalli', and he was an owner of horses.
Tha'labah bin Umm Hazna, from Banu Amir bin al-Harith, his horse: Ajla. He said about her:

book_title: Names of the Horses of the Arabs and Their Knights
text:
'And I prepared Ajla for the good medicine... a doctor feels her insides.'
Urwa bin Sinan al-Abdi, his horse: Quddam. He said about her:
'And upon Quddam I carried the armor of a decisive man... in fear, his heart is not burdened.'

**Horses of Al-Namir bin Qasit**
Abu Abdullah said: Al-Mundhir bin Ma' al-Sama' held a race, so the Arabs brought horses to him. A man from Kalb called Jariya bin Malik bin Jahl bin Awf bin Amr came to Al-A'lam bin Awf al-Namiri and asked for his mare. He gave it to him on condition that his son race it. He took it, a hairy mare with a wide belly, neighing and running fast. When the horses were released, the boy held its rein. The Kalbi said: "Release her! The horses have gone." He did not answer him until the horses disappeared, then he released her. She appeared to Al-Mundhir winning. The boy feared for his mare, so he went on his mare. Al-Mundhir seized the Kalbi for the mare and sent cavalry with him. He came to Al-A'lam. Al-A'lam said: "The mare belongs to my son, and he has gone out seeking grass that neither sheep nor camel can reach. If you find him sleeping and she has birthed a foal, then you are more likely to take him." They found him as he described. The boy heard the sound of horses, jumped up terrified, bridled her, and the horses followed him. The colt was by his knee in his saddlebag (kurz). The Kalbi said: "Many a run is in the saddlebag," and it became a proverb. The mare was called: Al-Raha. He said about her:
'O Amr, did you wonder at the colt of Al-Raha?'

book_title: Names of the Horses of the Arabs and Their Knights
text:
'And the horses behind him complain of soreness.'
Rabi'a bin Jusham had a horse called: Waqi', from her offspring. He had a daughter called: Al-Sabuh. He said about her:
'Umm Abdullah came to me blaming... and her desire is little achievable.
About the daughter of Waqi' when she saw her... the water-camels and the houses being humiliated for her.
She attributed wealth to her and followed it... with the scarcity of what we have; indeed we are sated.'
Al-Rawaya: Camels carrying water.
Qays bin Zuhayr al-Namiri, his horse on which Al-Mundhir bin Ma' al-Sama' escaped: Al-Jiryal. Qays bin Zuhayr al-Namiri was killed that day; Bakr bin Wa'il killed him on the Day of Kazim.

**Horses of Banu Wa'il**
The horse of Jabir bin Hunayy al-Taghlibi: Zaym. He said:
'This is the time of charging, so charge, Zaym... The night has wrapped her with a crashing driver.'

book_title: Names of the Horses of the Arabs and Their Knights
text:
'Neither a shepherd of camels or sheep... nor a butcher on a chopping block.
Slim of flanks, quick of foot.'
Abraha bin Umayr bin Kulthum, his horse: Al-Mudhhib. He said about it:
'Al-Mudhhib adorned the horses of the Taghlibis... just as his rider adorned him on the day of adversity.'
Abd Yaghuth bin Harb, his horse: Al-Sarih. Al-Akhtal said about it:
'And the children of Al-Sarih are marked... lions with folded ears and leopards are upon them.'
Amr bin Jabala al-Yashkuri, his horse: Al-Alah. He said about her:
'Why did I repel the spear of Abu Shurayh... and polish Al-Uqaysar?'
Al-Uqaysar: His sword.
'And I treated Al-Alah with the treatment of a skin... and did not use her during the year of drought.'
Dawa' mask: Meaning as the skin is treated.
Wa lam azhar biha: Meaning I did not neglect her.
'We persisted, may you have no father, so persist... And the other nights are not returned.'
Nafi' bin Abd al-Uzza bin Khawwas bin Malik bin Rabi'a bin Amir bin Juhayl bin Tha'labah bin Ghubbar bin Ghanm, his horse: Al-Zarqa'. He is called: The Knight of Al-Zarqa'.

book_title: Names of the Horses of the Arabs and Their Knights
text:
Al-Munfajir, from Banu Amir bin Ghubbar, his horse Al-Na'amah. He caught up with Banu Yashkur when they divided Mulham from a distance of two days in one morning. Mulham: A water of Al-Yamama, a village with many wells.
Qart bin al-Taw'am al-Adawi, his horse: Mayyar. He said about it:
'Ibn Shamma' used to give him evening and morning drink... from a herd like palm shoots, rotating.
I continued stabbing them sideways and hitting them... until they feared, so they have Mayyar from me.'
Muhalhil bin Rabi'a, his horse: Al-Mushahhar. He is the Knight of Al-Mushahhar. He said about it:
'Bring the tether of Al-Mushahhar near me... Every peer he meets means fighting.'
Al-Sarra' bin Qays bin Adi bin Qays bin al-Muftariq, his horse: Jalwa. Zuhayr bin Zabban bin Adi bin Qays bin al-Muftariq said about her:
'And a sayer on the day of defense to her husband... Al-Sarra' is not equaled in events.
A youth who turned back the horses, their throats bleeding... in defense, and the feet did not slip with him.
And Jalwa knew that her master is not... a weak obscure man nor a dullard.'
He meant: Bi-abam, so he changed the mim to nun, meaning the heavy, inarticulate one.
'And if Jalwa did not belong to the son of a free woman... the first of the vanguard would have perished with Jalwa.'

book_title: Names of the Horses of the Arabs and Their Knights
text:
**From Banu Shayban**
Al-Hawfazan bin Sharik, and his name is Al-Harith, his horse: Al-Kamil. Al-Anbari said about him:
'And Al-Hawfazan escaped us on Kamil.'
Qays bin Mas'ud, his horse: Al-Manih.
Bistam bin Qays, his two horses: Dhat al-Nusu' and Al-Za'faran.

**From Banu Qays bin Tha'labah**
Al-Harith bin Abbad, his horse: Al-Na'amah. He said about her:
'Bring the tether of Al-Na'amah near me... The war of Wa'il has conceived after being barren.'

**Horses of Banu Dhuhl bin Tha'labah**
Abu Abdullah said: Banu Sadus bin Shayban bin Dhuhl and Abu Rabi'a bin Dhuhl bin Shayban were the most generous of Bakr bin Wa'il in keeping horses.
To Banu Sadus belonged: Sawbah, Al-Mutamattir, and Bal'a'.

book_title: Names of the Horses of the Arabs and Their Knights
text:
And to Banu Abi Rabi'a: Al-Kharma'.
Al-Mutamattir belonged to Hayyan bin Murra bin Jandala bin Jasr bin Amr bin Sadus. He says about it:
'And the mean slave does not make his distress... And he does not make the workhorse like Al-Mutamattir.'
Also narrated: 'And the mean slave did not make his distress... And he did not make the workhorse like Al-Mutamattir.'
He also had Sawbah. Sawbah remained in the hands of Abdullah bin Hayyan. Al-Hasir bin al-Mutamattir and his mother Sawbah belonged to Abdullah bin Hayyan bin Murra. There was a dispute between Banu Awf bin Sadus and Amr bin Sadus. Qatan bin Abdullah bin Hayyan wounded a son of Khalifa bin Wathila. Banu Awf bin Sadus accepted Al-Hasir bin al-Mutamattir as compensation for their wounds. Abdullah bin Hayyan did that, then regretted it and enabled them over his son. Al-Aswad bin Rifa'a said:
'Abu Qatan chooses the splitting of his head... over a filly from the family of Sawbah or a colt.
They sought him so they might rob the Sheikh of his colt... And Al-Hasir would have sufficed us for the vengeance.'
He said: Bal'a' was the mare of Al-Aswad bin Rifa'a. He sold a filly of hers for ten thousand to Khalifa bin Wathila and delivered it. Then he left Basra in the time of Umar bin al-Khattab and extracted her [another foal?] from her mother's belly. He traveled from Basra to...

book_title: Names of the Horses of the Arabs and Their Knights
text:
...La'la', which is a village between Kufa and Basra, in one night, and his mare died under him. His sons said: 'You have destroyed us; you bought a horse for ten thousand.' He said: 'O my sons, I bought lineage for you.'
He said: Hazana bin al-Sukhayr told me that Banu Amr bin Sadus had five horses on the Day of Dhi Qar. He named four and left one.
He said: Abu Fayd bin Harmal bin Alqama bin Sadus had: Al-Mutaghayyif and Nadwa.
Kulthum bin al-Harith bin Ka'b bin Amr bin Sadus had: Mudrik bin al-Jazi. Al-Jazi belonged to Al-Harith bin Ka'b bin Amr.
He said: Aswad bin Shayban told me that Al-Harith bin Ka'b was one of the knights of Banu Amr bin Sadus who caught up with Sawad al-Yashkuri and killed him. He had killed Shaqiq al-A'war bin Abdullah bin Amr bin Sadus, who was the keeper of their idols.
Mu'arrij had a horse called: Al-Zalim, which Al-Nu'man bin Zur'a chased on the Day of Dhi Qar. He says to it:
'And Al-Nu'man escaped us by the distance of our spears... And at the rump of the colt was a brown sharp spear.'

book_title: Names of the Horses of the Arabs and Their Knights
text:
Fawt al-rimah: Slightly ahead of them. He says: He escaped it but did not get far. Al-Qatah of the beast: The place of the rider behind the saddle.
The horse of Abd Amr bin Rashid bin Jaz' bin Ka'b was called: Haydab. His wife Hadham bint Qays bin Saffarah bin Khuza'i bin al-A'war bin Sadus blamed him for preferring it. He said:
'You blamed regarding Haydab in the evening, and were it not for... the charge of Haydab, Hadham would have been widowed.'
The horse of Khazaz bin Lawdhan bin Awf bin Sadus was called: Al-Gharraf. He says about it:
'Do not mention my colt and what I fed her... for your color will become like the color of the scabby one.'
It is also narrated: Like the skin of the scabby one. He says in it:
'And your mount will be the young camel and its litter... and the son of Al-Na'amah at that time will be my mount.'
Abu Abdullah said: He is Al-Gharraf son of Al-Na'amah, and Al-Na'amah belonged to Khazaz bin Lawdhan.
Hassan bin Maslama bin al-Khazaz bin Lawdhan, his mare was called: Al-Ghashwa'. He says about her:
'Why did you detain Al-Ghashwa' among you... shining as if she were Sirius the Crosser?'

book_title: Names of the Horses of the Arabs and Their Knights
text:
'A favored group from you is with her... and another with her is locked, difficult.'
The horse of Ubayy bin Wathila bin Lu'ayy bin Awf: Ziyad, and his mother: Bal'a', and he is the one he bought for ten thousand.
The horse of Salama bin Nahar bin Abi al-Aswad bin Humran bin Amr bin al-Harith bin Sadus is named: Al-Jaradah.
The horse of Al-Khamkham bin Hamla bin Ubayy bin al-Aswad: Al-Maghra.
Abu Abdullah said: Kalb raided Banu Dhuhl on the Day of Al-Rawdah, but Banu Dhuhl defeated them after they had driven away the cattle. Salama bin Nahar said:
'Were it not for Al-Jaradah and Al-Ma'z, Jayda'... would not have seen her herd of long-humped camels.'
Jayda' bint Shabwah bin Abi al-Aswad.
Alqama bin Shihab bin Awf bin al-Harith bin Sadus, the Knight of Al-Hawwa'. He is also called: Ma'rur. Mutabba' bin Alqama said to his guests:
'My father is the Knight of Al-Hawwa', a night he did not find... for his guests anything but the bowl in the felt.'

book_title: Names of the Horses of the Arabs and Their Knights
text:
He said: And they recite this verse: My father is the Knight of Al-Ma'rur.
Sa'd bin Shuja' bin al-Harith bin Sadus, the Knight of Radwa. Nahar bin al-Aswad bin Humran bin Amr bin al-Harith said:
'The charge of Sa'd and Ibn Humran achieved it... and the dashing of Radwa behind her and Al-Khafaydad.'
Al-Khafaydad is the horse of Al-Aswad bin Humran bin Amr bin al-Harith.
The horse of Qatada bin Hariz bin Asaf bin Tha'labah bin Sadus: Al-Ta'ir.
The horse of Lahiq bin al-Najjar bin Humayri bin Tha'labah bin Sadus: Al-Nahhab. It was said about her:
'Al-Nahhab did not miss the bird.'
It was named Al-Nahhab because it neighs (yanhib) in its voice, which is less than a full neigh (sahil).
The horse of Mirdas bin Ja'wana bin Sama bin Sakhr bin Tha'labah bin Sadus: Al-Uqab. She is the one on which he overtook Muja'a bin Murara al-Hanafi and killed him. Muja'a had stabbed him before that a stab that made him bleed.
Habban bin Qatada, his horse is called: Al-Kafit. He said about it:

book_title: Names of the Horses of the Arabs and Their Knights
text:
'And my preferring Al-Kafit provoked Sa'd... and Ada while the knights know me.'
The horse of Jabir bin Aqil: Hudhlul. He said about it:
'Lo, who is for Hudhlul, a youth like Jabir... who returns Hudhlul as he used to do?'
Al-Mahrus bin Amr, from Banu Abdullah bin Sadus, his horse was called: Al-Ma'luq. He said about it:
'I praised that Ma'luq guarantees for us every craving... when our dry camels do not bring a milking vessel.'
The horse of Amr bin Shayban bin Dhuhl bin Tha'labah is named: Al-Tafi, and his she-camel Al-Ulkud. And his horse upon which Al-Azwar bin al-Harith bin Amr bin Shayban charged on the Day of Qidda; he is the one who captured Barra al-Qunfudh al-Taghlibi on it.
The horse of Malik bin Abda bin Rabi'a bin Amr bin Shayban bin Dhuhl is named: Raghwah. He said about her:
'I released Raghwah while the knights were roaming... And her master was neither an intruder nor inexperienced.'
He said: Al-Waghl: The one who enters upon people while they are drinking and drinks with them.
The horse of Al-Qa'qa' bin Shawr was named: Al-Matamir, and it was famous.

book_title: Names of the Horses of the Arabs and Their Knights
text:
Abu Abdullah said: Al-Mundhir bin Ma' al-Sama' said on the day he fled from Bakr bin Wa'il on the Day of Kazim: "I have tested the horses of Bakr bin Wa'il. They have four horses: As for the horse of Ruwaym bin Rabi'a, it is a sea (fast). As for the horse of Thumama bin al-Quraym, it is likely to lag." Ta'tham: fall short of the goal. "As for Al-Sayyid, its stab on the Day of Uwara holds it back. As for Al-Jammaza, the horse of Umayya bin Hantam bin Adi bin al-Harith bin Tamim Allah, it is the first to catch up."
Al-Sayyid: The horse of Mujalid bin Yathrabi bin al-Zabban.
The horse of Al-Harith bin Wa'la: Al-Mutafajjir. Yahya bin Mansur said:
'From us is Ibn Kawma when he risked himself... and Al-Sha'thaman and the Knight of Al-Mutafajjir.'
Huways bin Bujayr bin Murra, the Knight of Al-Nasib. A man from Banu Abd Shams said obliging his people:
'I shook off a vengeance for you with a setting knight... and left people whose wounds are being treated.'
The Knight of Khasaf: Hamal bin Badr bin Awf bin Amir bin Dhuhl. The poet said:
'By Allah, if I met Khasaf in the evening... I would be the most ominous knight against the kings.'
The horse of Al-Kalj: Al-Dakhil. He said on the Day of Kalb:

book_title: Names of the Horses of the Arabs and Their Knights
text:
'I exchanged Al-Dakhil for you... limping, so occupy his ropes.'
Yakus: Walking on three legs. He had killed Fadalah, and they hamstrung his horse. Fadalah: Abu Dahya al-Kalbi.
The horse of Qays bin Siba': Shu'la. Halza bin Abbad said:
'Were it not for the speed of Shu'la, you would not have returned... with the victory of a winner on the Day of Al-Anab.'
The horse of Wa'la bin Shurahil bin Zayd: Al-Amarrad. Al-Mudarib bin Nu'aym said:
'Indeed Al-Amarrad on the Day of Al-Khaw' gave freely of... the sweat of the family of A'naq, unblemished.'
A'naq: The horse of Amr bin Abi Rabi'a bin Dhuhl bin Shayban bin Tha'labah.

**Horses of Ijl bin Lujaym**
Al-Harith bin Dulaf, his horse is called: Al-Marikh, and he is the Knight of Al-Marikh.
Hanzala bin Sayyar al-Ijli, the Knight of Umayr, which is the name of his horse. He said on the Day of Dhi Qar, while he was on the left wing of Bakr bin Wa'il, encouraging them:

book_title: Names of the Horses of the Arabs and Their Knights
text:
'Your sects have become serious, so become serious.
What is my excuse while I am armed and tough?
And the bow has a strong string in it.
Like the arm of the young camel or stronger.
The news of my people has begun to appear.
And deaths, there is no escape from them.
This is Umayr, above him is the fierce one.
He advances him, he has no return.
Until he returns like the reddish-brown Kumayt.
Leave Banu Shayban and be unique.
My soul is your ransom, and my father the grandfather.'
And he said:
'Patience, Umayr, they are the Persian cavalries.
Patience, and let not a flying leg frighten you.
For my soul is patient for deaths.'

**Horses of Hanifa bin Lujaym**
Abdullah bin Abd, the Knight of Marhab.

**Horses of Iyad bin Nizar**
Abu Dawud, his horse: Al-Arada. He said about her:

book_title: Names of the Horses of the Arabs and Their Knights
text:
'Bring the tether of Al-Arada near, for the... war has in it anxieties and rugged grounds.'
And he said:
'Indeed Al-Ghamamah, Al-Sarih, and Lahiq... and the daughters of A'waj produce every swift horse.'
And it is narrated: In it are Al-Ghamamah, Al-Sabuh, and Lahiq.

**Horses of Yemen**
Al-As'ar bin Malik al-Ju'fi, his horse: Al-Mu'alla. He said about it:
'I want the blood of Banu Mazin... and the whiteness of milk pleased Al-Mu'alla.'
He also had: Al-Dhabih. He said about it:
'Indeed Al-Dhabih threw with his two sides... the stones and the Nassiy plant.'
Salama bin Yazid al-Ju'fi said about a stallion of theirs called: Ra'shan:
'And horses that witnessed Ra'shan... strong of joints, winning in the runs.'
Al-A'raj al-Ta'i, who is Adi bin Amr, his horse: Al-Ward.
'She blames me for giving Al-Ward a milk-camel... and she is not equal to Al-Ward in the hour we are frightened.'

book_title: Names of the Horses of the Arabs and Their Knights
text:
**Horses of Hamdan**
Al-Ajda' bin Malik, his horse's name: Sakab. He said about it:
'She scolds me when she sees my maintenance... of Sakab, and the best of horses is the one maintained.'
